revision.text:
A '''chordioid''', also called ''chord fragment'' or ''fragmentary voicing''Rawlins, Robert, et al. (2005) ''Jazzology: The Encyclopedia of Jazz Theory for All Musicians'', p. 86. Winona: Hal Leonard. {{ISBN|0634086782}}. or ''partial voicing'', is a group of musical notes which does not qualify as a [[chord (music)|chord]] under some preferred chord theory or other, but still useful to name and [[Reification (knowledge representation)|reify]] for other reasons. The main use of chordioids is to form "legitimate" chords [[enharmonic]]ally in [[12TET]] by adding one or more notes to this base.Slonimsky, Nicholas. (1947) ''Thesaurus of Scales and Melodic Patterns'', p. v. New York: Charles Scribner Sons. {{ISBN|002-6118505}}. It is typical of chordioids that many different resultant chords can be created from the same base depending on the note or combination of notes added. The resultant chords on a single chordioid are somewhat related, because they can be [[Chord progression|progressed between]] using motion of just one voice. Theorists – or practical music teachers – writing of chordioids usually go so far as to advise that students learn them in the practical manner of chords generally: in all [[transposition (music)|transpositions]], [[Range (music)|ranges]], [[permutations]], and [[voicing (music)|voicings]], for reading, writing, and playing.Slonimsky, Nicholas. (1947) ''Thesaurus of Scales and Melodic Patterns'', p. 241. New York: Charles Scribner Sons. {{ISBN|002-6118505}}. It is the case, also, that "legitimate chords" can be used as chordioids to create resultant chords by the same process.Schillinger, Joseph. (1941) ''The Schillinger System of Musical Composition, Vol. 1'', p. 478. New York: Carl Fischer. {{ISBN|0306775212}} Perhaps this is whence the non-chord chordioids come. The [[Augmented sixth chord#Italian sixth|Italian augmented 6th chord (It+6)]] is one example, from which proceed the [[Augmented sixth chord#French sixth|French augmented 6th chord (Fr+6)]] and [[Augmented sixth chord#German sixth|German augmented 6th chord (Gr+6)]] by addition of one note. Rawlins(2005) asserts that the notion derives from practice of such composers as [[Eric Satie]], [[Claude Debussy]], [[Maurice Ravel]], and [[Gabriel Faure]], and was first used in jazz by [[Bill Evans]]. Two chordioids may potentially be combined, as well. Typically, duplication of notes will result in a reduced number of unique notes in the resultant. Chordioids as a technique is related to [[polychord]]s insofar as polychords are the result of an additive process, but differs in that the basis of polychords is the addition of two known chords. Chordioids is related also to [[upper structure]]s as a technique insofar as upper structures represent groups of notes not commonly taken to be "legitimate" chords, but differs in that chordioids as a technique uses ''a priori'' structures held in common rather than a free selection of color tones appropriate for a lower integral chord. Chordioids is related to [[slash chord]]s as a technique insofar as known chords may be used as chordioids to create resultant scales, but differs in that chordioids used are not exclusively known chords. == Master chord == [[File:Master chord chardiod resultant chords.png|450px|thumb|center|Master chardiod resultant chords: added note = square note heads, implied notes=parenthesis]] [[Nicolas Slonimsky]] named "master chord" that chordioid described in [[jazz]] chord theory as [[Dominant seventh chord|7no5]], e.g.: {{nobreak|{ C D F{{music|sharp}} }. }} The sonority of the chordioid itself is identical to that of the [[Augmented sixth chord#Italian sixth|It+6]], a subset of the [[Wholetone scale]] and so subject to some of the [[Symmetry|symmetries]] and [[homogeneity]] for which that scale is known, and [[Anhemitonia|anhemitonic]] allowing the possibility that the resultant scale be anhemitonic or at least [[Ancohemitonia|ancohemitonic]] itself. The chord buttons of the [[Accordion]] usually play master chords, allowing the bass buttons (or a second chord button) to supply the variable note (or notes) to complete the sonority. The new name and concept, "master chord", thus does not imply either jazz derivation, completeness of the sonority as an independent chord, nor connection to other use as a chord of [[dominant function]]. It does not speciously denote anything to be "missing", or posit that the listener should ever hear a note not actually present. It rejects the tertian chordal basis as pertaining at all. These, the practicality of application, and the variety of use, are the logical basis of chordioids. The following table shows the resultant chord for some of the possible added notes: {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="4" | Master Chord: C D F{{music|sharp}} |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord !! Intervals !! Audio |- | E{{music|flat}} || D7{{music|flat}}9 || '''0''' '''4''' 7 '''t''' 1 || {{audio|Dominant minor ninth chord on C.mid|Play on C}} |- | E || E9{{music|sharp}}5 || 0 '''8''' '''t''' '''2''' || {{audio|Ninth augmented fifth chord on C.mid|Play on C}} |- | G{{music|sharp}} || G{{music|sharp}}({{music|sharp}}11),
[[Augmented sixth chord#French sixth|Fr+6]] to D{{music|flat}} || 0 '''4''' 7 '''t''' 2 '''6''',
'''0''' '''4''' 6 '''t''' || {{audio|Augmented eleventh chord on C.mid|Play on C}},
{{audio|Augmented dominant seventh chord.mid|Play on C}},
{{audio|French sixth moving to V.ogg|Fr+6 in C}} |- | A || D7,
[[Augmented sixth chord#German sixth|Gr+6]] to D{{music|flat}} || '''0''' '''4''' 7 '''t''' || {{audio|Dominant seventh chord on C.mid|Play on C}},
{{audio|German sixth moving to V.ogg|Gr+6 in C}} |- | B{{music|flat}} || C9{{music|flat}}5,
B{{music|flat}}7{{music|sharp}}5 || '''0''' 4 '''6''' t '''2''',
0 '''4''' '''8''' t '''2''' || {{audio|Ninth flat five chord on C.mid|Play on C}},
{{audio|Ninth augmented fifth chord on C.mid|Play on C}} |} == Non-dominant [[seventh chord|seventh]] chordioids == Robert Rawlins based his theory of chordioids off the above as well as [[permutation]]s of other major and minor [[seventh chord|7th chords]]. He described his chordiods as the interval of a [[Interval number|2nd]] below the interval of a [[Interval number|3rd]]. === Major === Based upon [[Major seventh chord|M7no5]], e.g.: { C D{{music|flat}} F }: {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C D{{music|flat}} FRawlins, Robert, et al. (2005) ''Jazzology: The Encyclopedia of Jazz Theory for All Musicians'', pg. 87. Winona: Hal Leonard. {{ISBN|0634086782}}. |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | E{{music|flat}} || E{{music|flat}}13 |- | F{{music|sharp}} || F{{music|sharp}}M7{{music|sharp}}11 |- | G || G11{{music|flat}}5 |- | A{{music|flat}} || D{{music|flat}}M7 |- | A || A({{music|flat}}13{{music|sharp}}9) |- | B{{music|flat}} || Csus4{{music|flat}}9, B{{music|flat}}m add2 |} === Major-minor === Based upon [[Minor major seventh chord|mM7no5]], e.g.: { C D{{music|flat}} F{{music|flat}} }: {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C D{{music|flat}} E |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | E{{music|flat}} || E{{music|flat}}13{{music|flat}}9 |- | G || G13/11{{music|flat}}5 |- | A{{music|flat}} || D{{music|flat}}mM7 |- | B{{music|flat}} || B{{music|flat}}m9{{music|flat}}5 |} === Minor === Based upon [[Minor seventh chord|m7no5]], e.g.: { C D F } , the sonority of the chordioid itself is [[Anhemitonia|anhemitonic]] allowing the possibility that the resultant scale be anhemitonic or at least [[Ancohemitonia|ancohemitonic]] itself. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C D F |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | E || E({{music|flat}}13{{music|flat}}9) |- | G || G7sus4 |- | A || Dm7 |- | B{{music|flat}} || B{{music|flat}}add2 |} == Incomplete [[seventh chord|sevenths]] and [[ninth chord|ninths]] chordioids == [[Joseph Schillinger]] based his theory of chordioids off the above as well as those irregular voicings of [[Seventh chord|7th]] chords in which the [[Fifth (chord)|5th]] is present but the [[Third (chord)|3rd]] absent, and of [[Ninth chord|9th]] chords in which the [[Fifth (chord)|5th]] and [[Third (chord)|3rd]] are both absent.Schillinger, Joseph. (1941) ''The Schillinger System of Musical Composition'', Vol. 1, p. 478. New York: Carl Fischer. {{ISBN|0306775212}} === Dominant seventh === Based upon [[Dominant seventh chord|7no3]], e.g.: { C G B{{music|flat}} } , the sonority of the chordioid itself is [[Anhemitonia|anhemitonic]] allowing the possibility that the resultant scale be anhemitonic or at least [[Ancohemitonia|ancohemitonic]] itself. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C G B{{music|flat}} |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | D || D({{music|flat}}13) |- | E{{music|flat}} || E{{music|flat}}6 |- | E || C7 |- | A{{music|flat}} || A{{music|flat}}M9 |- | A || Am7{{music|flat}}9 |} === M7 === Based upon [[Major seventh chord|M7no3]], e.g.: { C G B }: {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C G B |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | D || D13 |- | E || CM7 |- | A{{music|flat}} || A{{music|flat}}M{{music|sharp}}9 |- | A || Am9 |} === 7{{music|flat}}5 === Based upon [[Dominant seventh flat five chord|7{{music|flat}}5no3]], e.g.: { C G{{music|flat}} B{{music|flat}} } , the sonority of the chordioid itself is identical to that of the base triad of the [[Augmented sixth chord#French sixth|Fr+6]], a subset of the [[Wholetone scale]] and so subject to some of the [[Symmetry|symmetries]] and [[homogeneity]] for which that scale is known, and [[Anhemitonia|anhemitonic]] allowing the possibility that the resultant scale be anhemitonic or at least [[Ancohemitonia|ancohemitonic]] itself. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C G{{music|flat}} B{{music|flat}} |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | D || D({{music|flat}}13) |- | E{{music|flat}} || Cm7{{music|flat}}5, E{{music|flat}}m6 |- | E || C7{{music|flat}}5 |- | A{{music|flat}} || A{{music|flat}}9 |} === M7{{music|flat}}5 === Based upon M7{{music|flat}}5no3, e.g.: { C G{{music|flat}} B }: {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C G{{music|flat}} B |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | D || D13 |- | E{{music|flat}} || CmM7{{music|flat}}5 |- | E || CM7{{music|flat}}5 |- | A{{music|flat}} || A{{music|flat}}({{music|sharp}}9) |} === 7{{music|sharp}}5 === Based upon [[Augmented seventh chord|7{{music|sharp}}5no3]], e.g.: { C G{{music|sharp}} B{{music|flat}} } , the sonority of the chordioid itself is a subset of the [[Wholetone scale]] and so subject to some of the [[Symmetry|symmetries]] and [[homogeneity]] for which that scale is known, and [[Anhemitonia|anhemitonic]] allowing the possibility that the resultant scale be anhemitonic or at least [[Ancohemitonia|ancohemitonic]] itself. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C G{{music|sharp}} B{{music|flat}} |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | D || D7alt5 |- | E || C7{{music|sharp}}5 |- | A || AmM{{music|flat}}9 |} === M7{{music|sharp}}5 === Based upon [[Augmented major seventh chord|M7{{music|sharp}}5no3]], e.g.: { C G{{music|sharp}} B }: {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C G{{music|sharp}} B |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | D || D13{{music|flat}}5 |- | E || CM7{{music|sharp}}5 |- | A || AmM9 |} === Dominant 9 === Based upon [[Ninth chord#Dominant ninth|9no5no3]], e.g.: { C D B{{music|flat}} } , the sonority of the chordioid itself is a subset of the [[Wholetone scale]] and so subject to some of the [[Symmetry|symmetries]] and [[homogeneity]] for which that scale is known, and [[Anhemitonia|anhemitonic]] allowing the possibility that the resultant scale be anhemitonic or at least [[Ancohemitonia|ancohemitonic]] itself. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C D B{{music|flat}} |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | E{{music|flat}} || Cm9 |- | E || C9 |- | F || Dm({{music|flat}}13) |- | F{{music|sharp}} || D({{music|flat}}13) |} === M9 === Based upon [[Ninth chord#Major ninth|M9no5no3]], e.g.: { C D B }: {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C D B |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | E{{music|flat}} || CmM9 |- | E || CM9 |- | F || Dm13 |- | F{{music|sharp}} || D13 |} === Dominant {{music|flat}}9 === Based upon {{music|flat}}9no5no3, e.g.: { C D{{music|flat}} B{{music|flat}} } , the sonority of the chordioid itself is [[Anhemitonia|anhemitonic]] allowing the possibility that the resultant scale be anhemitonic or at least [[Ancohemitonia|ancohemitonic]] itself. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C D{{music|flat}} B{{music|flat}} |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | E{{music|flat}} || Cm{{music|flat}}9 |- | E || C({{music|flat}}9), D{{music|flat}}mM13 |- | F || D{{music|flat}}M13 |} === M{{music|flat}}9 === Based upon M{{music|flat}}9no5no3, e.g.: { C D{{music|flat}} B }, the sonority of the chordioid itself is [[Cohemitonia|cohemitonic]] assuring that the resultant scale be cohemitonic itself. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C D{{music|flat}} B |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | E{{music|flat}} || CmM{{music|flat}}9 |- | E || CM({{music|flat}}9) |} === Dominant {{music|sharp}}9 === Based upon {{music|sharp}}9no5no3, e.g.: { C D{{music|sharp}} B{{music|flat}} } , the sonority of the chordioid itself is [[Anhemitonia|anhemitonic]] allowing the possibility that the resultant scale be anhemitonic or at least [[Ancohemitonia|ancohemitonic]] itself. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C D{{music|sharp}} B{{music|flat}} |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | E || C({{music|sharp}}9) |- | G || Cm7 |} === M{{music|sharp}}9 === Based upon M{{music|sharp}}9no5no3, e.g.: { C D{{music|sharp}} B }: {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C D{{music|sharp}} B |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | E || CM{{music|sharp}}9 |- | G || CmM7 |} == Incomplete [[Eleventh chord|11ths]] chordioids == === Dominant 11 === Based upon 11no5no9 (or [[Suspended chord|7sus4]]), e.g.: { C F B{{music|flat}} }, the sonority of the chordioid itself is [[Anhemitonia|anhemitonic]] allowing the possibility that the resultant scale be anhemitonic or at least [[Ancohemitonia|ancohemitonic]] itself. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C F B{{music|flat}} |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | D || Dm{{music|flat}}13 |- | G || Gm11 |} === Major 11 === Based upon M11no5no9 (or [[Suspended chord|M7sus4]]), e.g.: { C F B }: {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | C F B |- ! Added Note !! Resultant Chord |- | D || Dm13 |- | G || G11 |} == [[Augmented sixth chord]]s == {{Main|Augmented sixth chord}} Harmonically, [[Augmented sixth chord|augmented sixth chords (+6ths) ]] in prime position require three things: * the interval of a [[major third]] up from the bottom note, * the interval of an [[augmented sixth]] up from the bottom note, and * strict [[anhemitonia]]: that there be no semitones present.Christ, William (1966). Materials and Structure of Music, v. 2, pp. 153ff. Englewood Cliffs: Prentice–Hall. LOC 66-14354.Tymoczko, Dimitri. (2011) ''A Geometry of Music'', pp. 61ff. New York: Oxford University. {{ISBN|978-0195336672}} . Given these requirements, which are minimally fulfilled by the [[Augmented sixth chord#Italian sixth|Italian sixth (It+6)]], e.g.: { A{{music|flat}} C F{{music|sharp}} }, it is possible to derive all potential +6 chords from the It+6. The following table illustrates:Prout, Ebenezer. (1889) ''Harmony: Its Theory and Practice'', pp. 197ff. London: Augener.( {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="2" | Italian +6th Chord: A{{music|flat}} C F{{music|sharp}}.Chadwick, G. (1897) ''Harmony: A Course of Study'', p. 134. Boston: B. F. Wood.Hanson, Howard. (1960) Harmonic Materials of Modern Music, pp. 356ff. New York: Appleton-Century-Crofts. LOC 58-8138. |- ! Added Note(s) !! Resultant Chord |- | B{{music|flat}}/A{{music|sharp}} || A{{music|flat}} B{{music|flat}}/A{{music|sharp}} C F{{music|sharp}} |- | E{{music|doubleflat}}/D || A{{music|flat}} C E{{music|doubleflat}}/D F{{music|sharp}} |- | E{{music|flat}}/D{{music|sharp}} || A{{music|flat}} C E{{music|flat}}/D{{music|sharp}} F{{music|sharp}} |- | E/D{{music|doublesharp}} || A{{music|flat}} C E/D{{music|doublesharp}} F{{music|sharp}} |- | B{{music|flat}}/A{{music|sharp}} & E{{music|doubleflat}}/D || A{{music|flat}} B{{music|flat}}/A{{music|sharp}} C E{{music|doubleflat}}/D F{{music|sharp}} |- | B{{music|flat}}/A{{music|sharp}} & E{{music|flat}}/D{{music|sharp}} || A{{music|flat}} B{{music|flat}}/A{{music|sharp}} C E{{music|flat}}/D{{music|sharp}} F{{music|sharp}} |- | B{{music|flat}}/A{{music|sharp}} & E/D{{music|doublesharp}} || A{{music|flat}} B{{music|flat}}/A{{music|sharp}} C E/D{{music|doublesharp}} F{{music|sharp}} |- | D & E || A{{music|flat}} C D E F{{music|sharp}} |- | B{{music|flat}}/A{{music|sharp}}, D & E || A{{music|flat}} B{{music|flat}}/A{{music|sharp}} C D E F{{music|sharp}} |} == Other known chords as chordioids == [[Joseph Schillinger]] also used basic triads and the master chord as chordioids in building bigger structures, textures, and strata. His [[Seventh chord|7th chords]] were based upon single notes added below [[Major chord|major]], [[Minor chord|minor]], [[Diminished triad|diminished]], or [[Augmented chord|augmented]] triads;Schillinger, Joseph. (1941) ''The Schillinger System of Musical Composition, Vol. 1'', p. 447. New York: Carl Fischer. {{ISBN|0306775212}} some of his hybrid 4-part harmony (including [[Eleventh chord|11th]] and [[Thirteenth chord|13th]] chords) likewise. == See also == * [[Factor (chord)]] == References == {{reflist}} {{Chords}} {{Jazz theory}} [[Category:Chords]] [[Category:Jazz techniques]] [[Category:Musical techniques]] [[Category:Jazz terminology]] [[Category:Musical terminology]]

{{Infobox video game |title = Chrono Quest |image = Chrono Quest cover.jpeg |caption = |developer = Infomedia |publisher = 16/32 Diffusion, [[Psygnosis Limited]] |platforms = [[Amiga]], [[Atari ST]] |released = September 1988 |genre = [[Adventure game|Adventure]] |modes = [[Single-player]] }} '''''Chrono Quest''''' (''Explora'' in France<ref name="Games Machine 1"/>) is an [[adventure game]] released in September 1988 for the [[Amiga]] and [[Atari ST]]. It was developed by French developer Infomedia and published by 16/32 Diffusion in France and [[Psygnosis Limited]] in the [[United Kingdom]].
The game received mixed to positive reviews from video game critics. A sequel to the game, ''Chrono Quest 2'', was released in 1989. ''Explora III: Sous le signe du serpent'' was never released in English, but saw a French release in 1990.
==Gameplay== ''Chrono Quest'' is an historical adventure game, where the player (accused of murdering their father) travels to different time periods on a quest to find their father's true murderer.
==Development== The game was developed by French software development house Infomedia and published by 16/32 Diffusion in [[France]] and [[Psygnosis Limited]] in the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name="Games Machine 1">{{Cite magazine|magazine=[[The Games Machine]]|publisher=[[Newsfield Publications]]|url=https://archive.org/stream/thegamesmachine-11/TheGamesMachine_11_Oct_1988#page/n13/mode/2up|title=Tough Guide|page=14|date=October 1988|issue=11}}</ref> The box art was designed by artist [[Roger Dean (artist)|Roger Dean]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://kotaku.com/5839158/giant-plastic-alien-heads-badass-fantasy-art--video-games/|title=Giant Plastic Alien Heads, Badass Fantasy Art & Video Games|last=Plunkett|first=Luke|work=[[Kotaku]]|publisher=[[Gizmodo Media Group]]|date=September 12, 2011|accessdate=December 5, 2017}}</ref>
==Reception== {{VG Reviews | CVG = 23/40<ref name="CVG">{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Computer & Video Games]]|publisher=[[Future plc]]|last=Campbell|first=Keith|url=https://archive.org/stream/cvg-magazine-087/CVG_087_Jan_1989#page/n94/mode/1up|title=Chrono Quest|page=95|date=January 1989|issue=87}}</ref> | rev1 = [[ACE (games magazine)|''ACE'']] | rev1Score = 221/400<ref name="ACE">{{cite magazine|magazine=[[ACE (games magazine)|ACE]]|publisher=[[Future plc]]|url=https://archive.org/stream/ace-magazine-15/ACE_Issue_15_1988_Dec#page/n99/mode/2up/search/Chrono|title=Chronoquest|page=101|date=December 1988|issue=15}}</ref> | rev2 = ''[[Commodore User]]'' | rev2Score = 32/40<ref name="ComUser">{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Commodore User]]|publisher=[[EMAP]]|last=Campbell|first=Keith|url=https://archive.org/stream/commodore-user-magazine-62/Commodore_User_Issue_62_1988_Nov#page/n89/mode/2up|title=Chrono Quest - Into the Valley|page=91|date=November 1988|issue=62}}</ref> | rev3 = ''[[The Games Machine]]'' | rev3Score = 86%<ref>{{cite magazine|magazine=[[The Games Machine]]|publisher=[[Newsfield Publications]]|url=https://archive.org/stream/thegamesmachine-magazine-13/TheGamesMachine_13#page/n32/mode/1up|title=Chrono-Quest|page=33|date=December 1988|issue=13}}</ref> }} ''Chrono Quest'' received mixed to positive reviews from video game critics
''Chrono Quest 2'' had a similar critical reception.<ref>http://www.stformat.com/stf12/pages_nx1500/stf12_069.jpg</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kultboy.com/index.php?site=t&id=11527|title=Kultboy.com - DIE Kult-Seite über die alten Spiele-Magazine und Retro-Games!|website=www.kultboy.com|access-date=2017-12-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/ace-magazine-34|title=ACE Magazine Issue 34|date=July 1990}}</ref>, While ''Explora 3'' received positive reviews.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://amr.abime.net/review_45797|title=Explora 3 review from Génération 4 28 (Dec 1990) - Amiga Magazine Rack|website=amr.abime.net|access-date=2017-12-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.amigaventure.fr/test/test_explora3.htm|title=Test Explora3|website=www.amigaventure.fr|access-date=2017-12-30}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{moby game|id=/chrono-quest}}

revision.text:
'''Cinéma du look''' ({{IPA-fr|sinema dy luk|lang}}) was a [[French film]] movement of the 1980s, analysed, for the first time, by French critic [[Raphaël Bassan]] in ''[[La Revue du Cinéma]]'' issue n° 448, May 1989,<ref>Translate in English : ''The French neo-baroques directors : Beineix, Besson, Carax from Diva to le Grand Bleu'' (pp. 11 – 23), in ''The Films of Luc Besson: Master of Spectacle'' (Under the direction of Susan Hayward and Phil Powrie) Manchester: Manchester University Press, 2007. {{ISBN|0-7190-7028-7}}</ref> in which he classified [[Luc Besson]], [[Jean-Jacques Beineix]] and [[Leos Carax]] as directors of "le look".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.scope.nottingham.ac.uk/bookreview.php?issue=14&id=1154 |title=Book Reviews: The Films of Luc Besson: Master of Spectacle |first=John |last=Berra |work=Scope |issue=14 |date=June 2009 |accessdate=2011-05-29}}</ref> These directors were said to favor style over substance, spectacle over narrative.<ref name=Austin>Austin, Guy. ''Contemporary French Cinema: An Introduction'', Manchester University Press, 1999, pp. 119–120, 126-128. {{ISBN|0-7190-4611-4}}</ref> It referred to films that had a slick, gorgeous visual style<ref name=Austin/> and a focus on young, alienated characters who were said to represent the marginalized youth of [[François Mitterrand]]'s France.<ref>French Cinema — Powrie & Reader</ref> Themes that run through many of their films include doomed love affairs, young people more affiliated to peer groups than families, a cynical view of the police, and the use of scenes in the [[Paris Métro]] to symbolise an alternative, underground society. The mixture of 'high' culture, such as the opera music of ''[[Diva (1981 film)|Diva]]'' and ''[[Les Amants du Pont-Neuf]],'' and pop culture, for example the references to [[Batman]] in ''[[Subway (film)|Subway]]'', was another key feature.<ref name=Austin/>
==Origins== French filmmakers were inspired by [[New Hollywood]] films (most notably [[Francis Ford Coppola]]'s ''[[One from the Heart]]'' and ''[[Rumble Fish]]''), late [[Rainer Werner Fassbinder|Fassbinder]] films (''[[Lola (1981 film)|Lola]]''), as well as television commercials, [[music video]]s, and fashion photography.{{sfn|Bordwell|Thompson|2003|p=620}}
==Key directors and key films==
===Jean-Jacques Beineix=== *''[[Diva (1981 film)|Diva]]'' (1981) *''La Lune dans le caniveau'' (English: ''[[Moon in the Gutter]]'') (1983) *''37°2 le matin'' (English: ''[[Betty Blue]]'') (1986)
===Luc Besson=== *''[[Subway (film)|Subway]]'' (1985) *''Le Grand bleu'' (English: ''[[The Big Blue]]'') (1988) *''[[Nikita (film)|Nikita]]'' (1990) *''[[Leon (film)|Leon]]'' (1993)
===Leos Carax=== *''[[Boy Meets Girl (1984 film)|Boy Meets Girl]]'' (1984) *''[[Mauvais Sang]]'' (1986) *''[[Les Amants du Pont-Neuf]]'' (1991)
==Notes==
===Footnotes=== <references/>
===Bibliography=== *{{Cite book|title=Film History: An Introduction |edition=2nd |first1=David |last1=Bordwell |first2=Kristin |last2=Thompson |year=2002 |isbn=0-07-038429-0 |ref=harv}}
==External links== *[http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/scope/documents/2004/february-2004/allmer.pdf Patricia Allmer - Institute of Film Studies, [[University of Nottingham]], 2004] *[http://lfnforever.tripod.com/id72.htm Will da Shaman, Netribution Film Network] *[http://www.nottingham.ac.uk/scope/documents/2000/november-2000/book-rev-nov-2000.pdf Guy Austin, ''Contemporary French Cinema: An Introduction'', A Review by J. Emmett Winn, see Austin pages 5 and 6] *[http://muse.jhu.edu/article/365356 ''Essays on Luc Besson : Master of Spectacle'' (review), by William Brown, 2009] *[https://books.google.fr/books?id=-Bbxa3q3ZZAC&pg=PA119#v=onepage&q=%22Cinéma%20du%20look%22 ''The Cinéma du look and fantasy films'', by [[Guy Austin]] in ''Contemporary French Cinema'', [[Manchester University Press]], 1996, p. 119] *[https://books.google.fr/books?id=nKd2VC2Q95YC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage ''Diva, Jean-Jacques Beineix'' in ''The Cinema of France'', by [[Phil Powrie]], p. 154, [[Wallflower Press]], 2006] *[https://books.google.fr/books?id=w2kSBwAAQBAJ&pg=PP5&lpg=PP5#v=onepage&q=Richard%20Ruston%20Cinema%20after%20Deleuze ''Luc Besson : The Cinema du Look or the Spectacle-Image'' in ''Cinema after Deleuze'' by Richard Ruston, [[Bloomsbury Publishing]], 2012, p. 132]
{{Film genres}}

{{For|the song by [[The Sunshine Underground]]|Raise the Alarm (disambiguation){{!}}Raise the Alarm}} {{italic title}} {{Use British English|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Commercial Breakdown | image = | show_name_2 = After the Break (1996) | genre = | presenter = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | num_episodes = 59 | runtime = 30–50 minutes | company = [[Celador]] | channel = [[BBC One|BBC1]] | picture_format = [[4:3]] (1989–2000)
[[16:9]] (2002–8) | first_aired = {{Start date|1989|12|29|df=yes}} | last_aired = {{End date|2008|8|3|df=yes}} | followed_by = ''[[Commercial Breakdown (Australian TV series)|Commercial Breakdown]]'' (Australian version) }} '''''Commercial Breakdown''''' is a [[light entertainment]] show that shows humorous [[television advertisement]]s from around the world and ran from 29 December 1989 to 3 August 2008 and aired on [[BBC One]]. British adverts were initially not allowed because of the BBC's [[Royal Charter]] (advertising is completely forbidden on the BBC), however presently, provided the adverts are not currently being broadcast, they are allowed. Many of the adverts were international which means they were not selling items on the British market. ==Transmissions== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! Start date !! End date !! Episodes !! Presenter |- | colspan="3"| 29 December 1989{{cite web |url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/ef608f404d1e4f0f89075143c7874ed8 |title=Carrott's Commercial Breakdown - BBC One London - 29 December 1989 |publisher=[[BBC Genome Project]] |accessdate=4 October 2016}} || rowspan="4"| [[Jasper Carrott]] |- | colspan="3"| 27 December 1991{{cite web |url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/d82d06fcd5794d2184b28fc618b9f5b9 |title=Carrott's Commercial Breakdown 2 - revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.5.2)
revision.text:
{{Infobox television | show_name = Dotchi no Ryōri Shō | runtime = | country = Japan | network = | image = DotchinoRyoriTitlecard.jpg | caption = | num_episodes = | creator = [[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation]] | starring = [[Hiroshi Sekiguchi]] and [[Yuji Miyake]] | narrated = | first_aired = April 17, 1997 | last_aired = March 17, 2005 }} The {{Nihongo|'''''Dotch Cooking Show'''''|どっちの料理ショー|Dotchi no Ryōri Shō|lead=yes}} (April 17, 1997 – March 17, 2005) was a [[Japan]]ese [[cooking show]] produced by the [[Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation]] and known for its use of the highest quality and most expensive food ingredients available from both domestic and international sources. In the show two chefs prepare two competing dishes, each using a special premium ingredient, but the dish that is ultimately served at the end of the show is determined by majority vote of the panelists, and then served only to those who voted for that dish. The show is continued by the {{Nihongo|[[#The New Dotch Cooking Show|'''''New Dotch Cooking Show''''']]|新どっちの料理ショー|Shin Dotchi no Ryōri Shō}} from April 14, 2005.
==Format== Each of the two hosts, [[Hiroshi Sekiguchi]] (関口宏) and [[Yuji Miyake]] (三宅裕司), chooses a particular dish for the contest, and oversees the dish's creation by his chef. For most of the show's run, Sekiguchi was in charge of the Red kitchen, and Miyake took the Yellow kitchen. In later episodes, the two dishes were pre-selected, and whichever meal Sekiguchi and Miyake prepared for his side was determined by a special dice throw. The competing dishes were typically from the same category; an example of a typical "battle" would be miso ramen versus salt-and-butter ramen. Other battles have included miso-based dishes versus mayonnaise-based dishes, chocolate fondant cake versus fruit tart, and even tacos versus spring rolls.
The seven guests would be asked to choose which meal they would most like to eat. Unlike [[Iron Chef]], where the judges would get to eat the food prepared by both chefs, only the guests who chose the winning dish were allowed to eat. There were three periods when the guests would vote; the first was when the dishes were announced, the second was after the "tasting time," and the third was after both dishes had been completed. Though Sekiguchi and Miyake would be allowed to taste the dishes in progress and describe what they had eaten (often in dramatic fashion), the guests were allowed only one "tasting time," where they got a sample of each kitchen's special ingredient, usually prepared in a manner similar to how it would be for the finished product. In the later episodes of the show, the tasting time was eliminated for all but one of the guests. The lucky guest, who was randomly chosen, would be allowed the samples as previously described, and would then have to describe what they tasted to the other guests. As a result, they would be the only one asked to choose the dish they wanted during the second voting. This was done to increase the suspense for the TV audience and put the guests on the same level as the audience.
While the chefs were preparing their dishes, each side would reveal a special ingredient that they hoped would sway the guests to vote for their respective dishes. The special ingredients could be anything from the focus of the recipe, such as a meat or vegetable, to a sauce or flavoring component. Though most of the special ingredients were found in often remote areas of Japan, some came from outside Japan, such as Mongolia, Korea, and even Scotland. In very rare and unusual instances, the special ingredients were not food items, but rather tools for preparing or serving the dish, such as a granite bowl from Korea, used in the preparation of stone-cooked [[bibimbap]], or a special cast iron press used to make [[taiyaki]]. Each kitchen's special assistant would go to where the special ingredient was grown/raised/manufactured/harvested, to both procure the special ingredient and observe how it was produced.
At the end of the show, the two hosts would declare in unison: "{{Nihongo|''Kon'ya no gochūmon wa dotch?''|今夜の御注文はどっち？||Which dish will you order for tonight?}}" The word "{{Nihongo|''Dotch''|どっち|Dotchi}}", which appears in the show's graphics, is a transliteration of the Japanese word meaning "which one". The guests would press a button (corresponding to which dish they chose) and the side with the most votes was declared the winner. The winning host would then ask the loser to withdraw (''tesshū'', 撤收). The losing host and his chef would then take away their losing dish, and the winning guests and host would then dine on their selection. The hungry losers would watch the winners eat. This would often be followed by a scene of the winning host and guests leaving the show set satisfied after their meal, a scene of the losing host and guests griping about not getting to eat as they left the studio, or sometimes both. At the very end of the show, the losing chef would typically be shown eating his dish alone, wondering why he did not win.
Since each side had to prepare food for eight people (seven guests and the winning host, in the event of a complete 7-0 victory (later 9 portions for seven guests, the winning host, and the assistant for the winning kitchen) and typically fewer than that number would actually get to eat, any food left over after the winners had eaten was usually consumed by the show's crew. Since each show usually took hours to film, the hunger expressed by the losing guests at the end was genuine.
==Attendants== * Sekiguchi's Kitchen ** Sekiguchi Hiroshi ** Sekiguchi's Assistant: Sosuke Sumitani (炭谷宗佑, an announcer at Nippon TV) ** Sekiguchi's Chef ** Sekiguchi's Mascot: DOTCHkun (ドッチくん) - Voiced by Aya Hara (原亜弥) [Later episodes of The New Dotch Cooking Show: Keisuke Mori (森圭介, an announcer at Nippon TV) becomes the new assistant]
* Miyake's Kitchen ** Miyake Yuji ** Miyake's Assistant: Ken Shimizu (清水健, an announcer at Yomiuri TV) ** Miyake's Chef ** Miyake's Mascot: WHICHkun (WHICHくん)- Voiced by Yuuko Mita (三田ゆう子) * Regular guest: [[Tsuyoshi Kusanagi]] (草彅剛) * 6 other guests, usually famous Japanese [[entertainer]]s or [[sportsperson|athlete]]s.
The assistants reported, newscaster-style, on the obtaining of special ingredients. The chefs were hired from a pool of highly skilled cooks.
==The New Dotch Cooking Show== The format of the show is basically the same, except that tasting time has been completely eliminated for the contestants (Sekiguchi and Miyake still get to taste the works in progress). The contestant roster was expanded from 7 to 11 (occasionally 9), with 4 celebrity contestants (Tsuyoshi Kusanagi still appeared as a regular) and 7 (occasionally 5) additional contestants, called "Hara-Helicopters," drawn from a pool. Typically, the Hara-Helicopters are everyday people, though some groups are distinctly categorized, e.g. schoolchildren, "idols," "young men who have not eaten for 48 hours," or restaurateurs. During the preparation of the meals, the celebrity contestants would be allowed to observe each chef's methods up close, and smell/feel (not taste) the various ingredients used, while the Hara-Helicopters would watch the action from their seats overlooking the stage. In some episodes, Kusanagi would bring a plate of one of the special ingredients up to the Hara-Helicopters so they could smell it. The series went on hiatus on September 14, 2006 and returned on January 4, 2007 for a one-time only TV special. [https://web.archive.org/web/20060205222732/http://www.ytv.co.jp/docchi/dotch_set.html]
==Airing time in JST== *28 NNS stations: 9:00 p.m. - 9:54 p.m. every Thursday *TV Miyazaki: 8:00 a.m. - 8:55 a.m. every Sunday *Oita Broadcasting Sys., Inc.: 6:55 p.m. - 7:49 p.m. every Thursday *Ryūkyū Broadcasting Corporation: 2:54 p.m. - 3:50 p.m. every Saturday
==Foreign broadcasts== *[[KIKU-TV]] runs a subtitled version of the show, billing as '''Dotchi no Ryori'''<ref>KIKU-TV [http://kikutv.com/dotchi-no-ryori.asp ''KIKU Television : Dotchi no Ryori''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902034359/http://kikutv.com/dotchi-no-ryori.asp |date=September 2, 2009 }} Accessed (2009-08-10)</ref> *[[United Television Broadcasting Systems|UTB]] Hollywood runs a subtitled version of show, billing as '''Cooking Showdown''' for on the English version of the website and '''どっちの料理ショー''' for the Japanese version of the website.<ref>UTBHollywood [http://utbhollywood.com/en/variety/cookingshow/index.php ''UTBHollywood/Cookingshow''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090520185147/http://utbhollywood.com/en/variety/cookingshow/index.php |date=May 20, 2009 }}</ref> * [[KSCI]] in the Los Angeles area broadcasts Dotch on channel 18.2 at 9:00 PM on Mondays.
==Episode list== {{Main|List of Dotch Cooking Show episodes}}
==See also== * [[Iron Chef]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060117092122/http://www.ytv.co.jp/docchi/dotch_set.html The New Dotch Cooking Show] (Yomiuri TV, in Japanese)
[[Category:Japanese cooking television series]] [[Category:Sports entertainment]] [[Category:1997 Japanese television series debuts]] [[Category:2005 Japanese television series endings]] [[Category:Yomiuri Telecasting Corporation shows]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = {{noitalics|EQ Music}} | logo = EQ Music Logo.jpg | logo_size = 200px | screenshot = | collapsible = | collapsetext = | caption = | url = {{URL|www.eqmusicblog.com}} | alexa = {{IncreaseNegative}} 2,968,416 ({{as of|2018|6|02|alt=June 2018}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/http://eqmusicblog.com |title= EQMusicBlog.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2018-06-02 }}</ref><!--Updated monthly by OKBot.--> | commercial = | type = [[Music blog]], [[website]] | language = English | registration = None | owner = Raj Rudolph | author = | editors = {{hlist | Raj Rudolph | Mandy Rogers | Luis Gonzalez}} | launch date = {{nowrap|{{start date and years ago|mf=yes|2005}}}} | current status = Online | revenue = | content license = }}
'''EQ Music Blog''' (formerly Electroqueer.com) is an independent British music [[website]] and [[blog]] founded by American digital and music enthusiast Raj Rudolph.<ref>{{cite web| |url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/rajrudolph| title=Raj Rudolph | work=[[Linkedin]]| |accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref> Alternative names include '''EQ''' and '''EQ Music'''; the site supports new [[electronic pop]] artists alongside its music reviews, features, interviews and video previews. In 2007, with the addition of New Artists Editor Mandy Rogers, the site developed into a multi-author blog; in 2013, pop blogger Luis Gonzalez joined.
In 2008, the EQ Music brand began to spoke into several entertainment related divisions including live showcasing, touring, [[record label]] and artist management; together, EQ Music's brands consolidate into a diverse international music [[media group]].
== History == In 2005, digital and music enthusiast Raj Rudolph launched Electroqueer.com as a blog focused on discovering and inspiring new talent in the [[Pop music|pop]] and [[Electronic music|electronic]] genres of music. In 2008, EQ Music Live was formed, with the subsequent formation of the EQ Music Tour in 2011.
At the 2008 [[The Weblog Awards (Bloggies)|Weblog Awards]], Electroqueer.com placed as finalist in the Best Music Blog category.<ref name="Best Music Blog Finalists 2008">{{cite web|last1=Kevin|first1=Aylward|title=Best Music Blog|url=http://2008.weblogawards.org/polls/best-music-blog/|website=2008.weblogawards.org|accessdate=2 June 2015|date=31 December 2008}}</ref> In 2010, Electroqueer.com changed its name, becoming EQ Music Blog. The following year, [[Wales|Welsh]] [[electropop]] duo [[Electrovamp]] won EQ Music Blog's theme song contest; the band's winning entry, "Electroqueer", became the site's official theme song and was featured on volume one of the ''This Beat Is Poptronik'' compilation album, curated by the blog.<ref name="EQMusicBlog Theme Song Winners">{{cite web|title=Announcing The Winner Of The 2011 EQ Music Theme Song Community Project – Electrovamp!|url=http://eqmusicblog.com/announcing-the-winner-of-the-2011-eq-theme-song-community-project-electrovamp/|website=EQMusicBlog.com|accessdate=7 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="Poptronik Vol. 1 - Itunes">{{cite web| |url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/this-beat-is-poptronik-volume/id520123239| title=This Beat Is Poptronik – Volume One | work=[[Itunes store]]| |accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref>
In 2012, EQ Music announced co-sponsorship from [[Gaydar Radio]], [[Budweiser]] and Music Jobs Ltd for the inaugural Poptronik Festival held in Spain.<ref name="UK.music-jobs.com Poptronik Festival 2012" /><ref name="Sitgesevents.com Poptronik Festival">{{cite web|title=Sitges Poptronik Festival 2014|url=http://www.sitgesevents.com/event/sitges-poptronik-festival-2014|website=Sitgesevents.com|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref>
In 2013, EQ Music launched its artist management division.<ref name="Mrwillwong.com EQ Management">{{cite web|title=NEWMUSIC: PARRALOX & RYAN ADAMÉS – "SILENT MORNING"|url=http://www.mrwillwong.com/newmusic-parralox-ryan-adames-silent-morning/|website=Mrwillwong.com|accessdate=9 June 2015|date=1 May 2013|quote=Electroqueer officially has branched into Artist Management over in the UK}}</ref> In 2015, the brand launched on [[Viber]] Public Chats, giving app users the ability to access the [[blogsite]]'s music picks and recommendations via the platform's [[instant messaging]] and [[Voice over IP]] (VoIP) software.<ref name="Viber">{{cite web| |url=http://chats.viber.com/eqmusic| title=EQ Music on Viber Public Chats | work=[[Viber]]| |accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref>
==Writing style and criticism== At its heart, EQ Music Blog describes itself as "a fun place to discover new music, watch music videos and dig deeper into the lives of the people creating quality electronic pop music, written with a fun and constructive tone."<ref name="Zoominfo.com EQ Music Blog">{{cite web|title=EQ Music Blog|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/s/#!search/profile/company?companyId=359284985&targetid=profile|website=Zoominfo.com|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> The site's editorial views have been featured in British press (''[[The Guardian (newspaper)|The Guardian]]'', ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|The Metro]]'' and ''[[Daily Star (British newspaper)|The Daily Star]]'').<ref name="The Guardian One Direction">{{cite web| |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2011/jan/18/jeremy-joseph-gay-one-direction| title=Is there only One Direction for G-A-Y? | work=[[The Guardian (newspaper)|The Guardian]]| |accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="The Metro Lady Gaga">{{cite web| |url=http://metro.co.uk/2010/03/01/lady-gaga-at-londons-o2-arena-gig-review-135258| title=Lady Gaga hailed as ‘new Queen of Pop’ after triumphant O2 gig | work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|The Metro]]| |accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="The Daily Star Patrick Wolf">{{cite web| |url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/gossip/64671/Wolf-attacked-at-Madonna-show| title=Wolf 'attacked' at Madonna show | work=[[Daily Star (British newspaper)|The Daily Star]]| |accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref>
In 2009, Australian blogsite PopTrashAddicts accused EQ Music of spending most of its time copying content from other pop blogs; a view EQ called a good laugh.<ref name="EQ Wins Worst Music Blog Pop Trash Addicts!">{{cite web|title=EQ Wins Worst Music Blog From Pop Trash Addicts!|url=http://eqmusicblog.com/eq-wins-worst-music-blog-from-pop-trash-addicts/|website=EQMusicBlog.com|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> In 2011, [[BBC News Online]] selected EQ Music's Raj Rudolph as an influential UK-based music editor and [[Sound of]] pundit, an accolade consecutively held since 2011—2015.<ref name="Sound of 2011" /><ref name="Sound of 2015">{{cite web| |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/3S3vM9fKwyr0w0vbxhl4KG5/the-pundits| title=Sound of 2015: Pundits | work=[[BBC News]]| |publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="Sound of 2012">{{cite web|title=Sound of 2012: Pundits|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/soundof/2012/pundits/az/|website=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref>
== Format ==
=== EQ Music Live === In 2008, EQ Music expanded its online artist promotion platform to include live music events showcasing both emerging and established pop and electronica artists.<ref name="Out Mag EQ Live">{{cite journal|title=Scene: Electroqueers|journal=Out In The City|date=1 September 2008|issue=21|page=80|url=http://www.outmag.co.uk/issues/outinthecitysept08.pdf|accessdate=9 June 2015}}</ref> In blogger Oli Freke's assessment of the launch night, he wrote "great atmosphere, great crowd and great start to a new electro night."<ref name="EQ1 @ Barcode Launch 2008">{{cite web|last1=Freke|first1=Oli|title=EQ1 @ Barcode|url=https://sounddesignarticles.wordpress.com/2008/06/20/eq1-barcode|website=Sounddesignarticles.wordpress.com|accessdate=9 June 2015|date=20 June 2008|quote=I concur with his assessment of the evening; great atmosphere, great crowd and great start to a new electro night.}}</ref>
EQ Music Live has celebrated residencies in Underbelly (Hoxton), Barcode (Soho) and Road Trip & The Workshop (Shorerditch).<ref name="EQ Music Live Underbelly, Hoxton">{{cite web|title=EQ Music Live Presents: Dangerous Muse|url=http://dangerousmuse.brownpapertickets.com/|website=DangerousMuse.brownpapertickets.com|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="EQ Music Live Road Trip & The Workshop">{{cite web|title=EQ Live Surprise Secret Show @ The Workshop with The Good Natured & Bim|url=http://heyevent.com/event/iw3wgikgaouwma/eq-live-surprise-secret-show-the-workshop-with-the-good-natured-bim|website=Heyevent.com|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> Artists showcased include [[The Good Natured]], [[Christian Burns]], [[Graffiti6]], [[Polly Scattergood]], [[Parralox]], [[Bright Light Bright Light]] and [[Simon Curtis (actor)|Simon Curtis]].<ref name="EQ Music Live Road Trip & The Workshop" /><ref name="RoadTripBar.com Polly Scattergood">{{cite web|title=EQ Music Live Presents: Polly Scattergood Plus Support|url=http://www.roadtripbar.com/event.php?event=MMAG605828EFSFPGEJ|website=RoadTripBar.com|accessdate=8 June 2015|date=7 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="HeyEvent.com Simon Curtis Live">{{cite web|title=EQ Live Presents Simon Curtis, Andrea Lewis & Ro Danishei|url=http://heyevent.com/event/4phfnjwsww6bua/eq-live-presents-simon-curtis-andrea-lewis-ro-danishei|website=HeyEvent.com|accessdate=8 June 2015|date=14 May 2011}}</ref>
=== EQ Music Tour === On 4 August 2011, EQ Music announced its first North American Music Tour headlined by American electropop singer Adam Tyler.<ref name="EQ Music Live tour announcement">{{cite web|title=ANNOUNCEMENT: First Ever EQ MUSIC TOUR featuring Adam Tyler Kicks Off In New York City on August 23rd – Full Tour Dates Revealed|url=http://eqmusicblog.com/announcement-first-ever-eq-music-tour-featuring-adam-tyler-kicks-off-in-new-york-city-on-august-23rd/|website=EQMusicBlog.com|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="HeyEvent.com EQ Music tour">{{cite web|title=EQ Music Tour featuring Adam Tyler|url=http://heyevent.com/event/162101553868170/eq-music-tour-featuring-adam-tyler|website=HeyEvent.com|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> The ten state, thirteen city US tour supported Tyler's debut album, ''Shattered Ice'' (2011).
====Tour dates==== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! width="140"| Date ! width="140"| City ! width="220"| Venue |- style="background:#ddd;" |- |August 23, 2011 |[[New York City|New York]] |Splash Night Club |- |August 24, 2011 |[[Chicago, IL|Chicago]] |Spin Night Club |- |August 25, 2011 |[[Cleveland, OH|Cleveland]] |Bounce Night Club |- |August 26, 2011 |[[Pittsburgh, PA|Pittsburgh]] |Cruze Bar |- |August 27, 2011 |[[Charlotte, NC|Charlotte]] |Charlotte Gay Pride |- |August 28, 2011 |[[Nashville, TN|Nashville]] |Play Night Club |- |August 31, 2011 |[[Pensacola, FL|Pensacola]] |Emerald City Night Club |- |September 1, 2011 |[[Atlanta, GA|Atlanta]] |Jungle Night Club |- |September 2, 2011 |[[Tampa, FL|Tampa]] |Honey Pot Night Club |- |September 3, 2011 |[[Wilton Manors, FL|Wilton Manors]] |Bill's Filling Station |- |September 4, 2011 |[[Houston, TX|Houston]] |Southbeach |- |September 7, 2011 |[[Austin, TX|Austin]] |Charlie's Austin Night Club |- |September 8, 2011 |[[San Francisco, CA|San Francisco]] |The Crib |- |September 9, 2011 |[[San Diego, CA|San Diego]] |Rich's Night Club |- |September 10, 2011 |[[Las Vegas, NV|Las Vegas]] |Krave Night Club |- |}
In November 2011, EQ Music sponsored [[Daniela Brooker]] as headliner for their second North American Music Tour.<ref name="Broadwayworld.com Daniela Brooker EQ Tour">{{cite web|title=Daniela Brooker To Headline Pinktober/EQ Music Tour|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwmusic/article/Daniela-Brooker-To-Headline-PinktoberEQ-Music-Tour-20111016#|website=Broadwayworld.com|accessdate=9 June 2015|date=17 October 2011}}</ref> Working in conjunction with [[Hard Rock International|Hard Rock Cafe]] on behalf of the [[American Cancer Society]]'s global [[Pinktober]] breast cancer awareness campaign, the fifteenth date live music tour began in [[Philadelphia]] (October 17) and ended in [[Palm Springs]] (November 6).<ref name="Downtownstl.org Pinktober Tour">{{cite web|title=Pinktober at Hard Rock Cafe|url=http://www.downtownstl.org/event/pinktober-at-hard-rock-cafe/|website=Downtownstl.org|accessdate=8 June 2015|date=28 October 2011}}</ref>
=== Poptronik albums and festival === In 2012, EQ Music launched the Poptronik brand which includes the ''This Beat Is Poptronik'' compilation series. On 16 April 2012, EQ Music in partnership with electropop [[Dance-pop|dance]] label, Aztec Records released ''This Beat Is Poptronik - Volume One''.<ref name="Poptronik Vol. 1 - Itunes" /><ref name="Aztec This Beat Is Poptronik vol.1">{{cite web|title=This Beat Is Poptronik – Volume One|url=http://www.aztecrecords.com/release/this-beat-is-poptronik-volume-one|website=AztecRecords.com|accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> ''So So Gay Magazine''{{'}}s Greg White commented "great quality electro-pop is exactly what we find on this huge compilation."<ref name="SoSoGay.co.uk Poptronik Vol.1 Review">{{cite web|last1=Greg|first1=White|title=ALBUM REVIEW: VARIOUS ARTISTS – THIS BEAT IS POPTRONIK: VOLUME ONE|url=http://sosogay.co.uk/2012/album-review-various-artists-this-beat-is-poptronik-volume-one/|website=SoSoGay.co.uk|accessdate=9 June 2015|date=21 May 2012}}</ref>
On 1 September 2012, [[Andy Bell (singer)|Andy Bell]], [[Fernando Garibay]], [[Cazwell]] and [[Monarchy (band)|Monarchy]] co-headlined EQ Music's inaugural two-day Poptronik Festival in [[Sitges]], [[Spain]]. [[Gaydar Radio]]ʼs Phil Marriott, [[Faithless]] percussionist [[Sudha Kheterpal]] and [[Scissor Sisters]]' Tour DJ – Sammy Jo were joined by a plethora of new and emerging electronic pop artists.<ref name="UK.music-jobs.com Poptronik Festival 2012">{{cite web|title=Poptronik Festival 2012 – With headliners Kazaky, Monarchy and Martika|url=http://uk.music-jobs.com/blog/index.php/gig-news/poptronik-festival-2012-with-headliners-kazaky-monarchy-and-martika|website=UK.music-jobs.com|accessdate=2 June 2015|date=4 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| |url=http://www.residentadvisor.net/event.aspx?320670| title=Poptronik Festival - Sitges at Sitges Beach | work=[[Resident advisor]]| |accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="Poptronik DJ Sudha">{{cite web|title=Poptronik Festival Sitges|url=http://www.boomsitges.com/blog/category/poptronik-festival-sitges-2|website=BoomSitges.com|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref>
On 27 August 2013 EQ Music released ''This Beat Is Poptronik - Volume Two'' under its own label.<ref>{{cite web| |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/this-beat-is-poptronik-vol.-2./id687376051?ign-mpt=uo%3D4| title=This Beat Is Poptronik – Volume Two | work=[[Itunes store]]| |accessdate=3 June 2015}}</ref> The album featured [[Carmen Electra]], [[Cherry Cherry Boom Boom]], [[Frankmusik]], [[Jessica Sutta]] (formerly of The Pussycat Dolls), [[Private (band)|Private]], [[Max Barskih]], [[Dangerous Muse]] and [[Jennifer Paige]].
In 2014, the label released Adam Tyler's ''Shattered Ice (Deluxe Edition)'' and Naommon's single, "Beginning Everyday".<ref name="Shattered Ice Delux - Itunes">{{cite web| |url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/shattered-ice-deluxe-edition/id880179405| title=Shattered Ice (Deluxe Edition) | work=[[Itunes store]]| |accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="Beginning Everyday - Itunes">{{cite web| |url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/album/beginning-everyday/id868110693| title=Beginning Everyday | work=[[Itunes store]]| |accessdate=8 June 2015}}</ref>
=== Artist management === In 2013, EQ Music launched its artist management operation and currently represents [[Australian]] electronic pop duo [[Parralox]], Latin artist Ryan Adamés from [[Los Angeles]], singer-songwriter Francine from [[London]], [[New York City|New York]] based [[alternative pop]] artist Daniel Robinson and [[Electronic dance music|EDM]] prodigy Mi Disguise from [[Los Angeles]].<ref name="Mrwillwong.com EQ Management" /><ref name="EQ Music Artists">{{cite web|title=EQ Music Artists|url=http://eqmusicblog.com/eq-music-artists|website=EQMusicBlog.com|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref>
== Accolades == * Electroqueer.com ranked fifth amongst Top 10 finalists of the 2008 [[The Weblog Awards (Bloggies)|Weblog Awards]] for Best Music Blog.<ref name="Best Music Blog Finalists 2008" /> * EQ Music Blog founder Raj Rudolph was a guest panellist at the first ever [[LGBT]] [[Winter Music Conference]] 2013.<ref name="WMC">{{cite web|last1=Woo|first1=Jen|title=Winter Music Conference to have first ever LGBT panel|url=http://dot429.com/articles/1629-winter-music-conference-to-have-first-ever-lgbt-panel|website=Dot429.com|accessdate=24 June 2015|date=8 March 2013}}</ref><ref name="2013WMC">{{cite web|title=WMC 2013 SCHEDULE|url=http://wintermusicconference.com/events/schedule/2013|website=WinterMusicConference.com|accessdate=24 June 2015|date=15 March 2013}}</ref> * EQ Music Blog ranked amongst Top 100 Music Blogs of 2015.<ref name="Top 100 Music Blogs 2015">{{cite web|last1=Popejoy|first1=Sarah|title=Musicians Empowered|url=http://buildingabrandonline.com/MusiciansEmpowered/top-100-music-blogs-2015-by-genre/|website=BuildingABrandOnline.com|accessdate=8 June 2015|date=2 February 2015}}</ref> * EQ Music Blog founder Raj Rudolph was consecutively selected to [[BBC News Online]]'s [[Sound of]] pundit list of influential online music editors between 2011—2015.<ref name="Sound of 2011">{{cite web|title=Sound of 2011: Pundits|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/soundof/2011/pundits/categories/|website=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=26 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="Sound of 2015" /><ref name="Sound of 2013">{{cite web|title=Sound of 2013: Pundits|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/profiles/3LBRKJsFcGnRk9m073zqW3C/the-pundits|website=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref>
