revision.text:
{{For|the saxophonist and bandleader|Tony Pastor (bandleader)}} {{Infobox writer | name = Tony Pastor | image = Tony-Pastor-01.JPG | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date|1837|5|28}} | birth_place = [[Manhattan, New York]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1908|8|26|1837|5|28}} | death_place = [[Elmhurst, Queens|Elmhurst]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | occupation = Vaudeville Entertainer, Showman and Theater Manager | yearsactive = 1867–1903}} '''Tony Pastor''' (May 28, 1837 – August 26, 1908) was an American [[impresario]], variety performer and theatre owner who became one of the founding forces behind [[United States|American]] [[vaudeville]] in the mid- to late-nineteenth century. He was sometimes referred to as the "Father of Vaudeville". The strongest elements of his entertainments were an almost [[jingoism|jingoistic]] brand of [[United States]] patriotism and a strong commitment to attracting a mixed-gender audience, the latter being something revolutionary in the male-oriented variety halls of the mid-century.{{cite book | author=Snyder, Robert W. | title=The Voice of the City: Vaudeville and Popular Culture in New York | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1989 | isbn=0-19-505285-4 }} A collection of his papers is maintained at the [[Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center]] at the [[University of Texas]] in Austin,{{cite web |title=Tony Pastor: An Inventory of His Collection |url=http://research.hrc.utexas.edu:8080/hrcxtf/view?docId=ead/00106.xml |publisher=Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center |accessdate=2014-12-23}} and in the archives of the [[New York Public Library for the Performing Arts]].{{cite web |title=Tony Pastor collection |url=http://www.nypl.org/archives/4785 |publisher=New York Public Library |work=Archives & Manuscripts |accessdate=2014-12-23}} ==Life and career== After his Spanish father (Antonio Pastor) came to New York and met his future wife Cornelia Buckley, from [[New Haven, Connecticut]], they lived in Manhattan. Their third child, and first son, Antonio Pastor, was born in [[Manhattan]] on May 28, 1837, at his parents' residence at 400 [[Greenwich Street]], in what is now the financial district of lower Manhattan. His father was a Spanish immigrant who supported his family as a barber and part-time musician.{{cite book |first=Armond |last=Fields |title=Tony Pastor, Father of Vaudeville |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XlCFnqopzQ4C&pg=PA4 |year=2007 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=978-0-7864-3054-3 |pages=4–6}}{{cite book |first=Parker |last=Zellers |title=Tony Pastor: Dean of the Vaudeville Stage |publisher=Eastern Michigan University Press |year=1971}}{{cite book |first=William Ellis |last=Horton |title=About Stage Folks |year=1902 |publisher=Free Press Printing |page=9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tQQOAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA9}} ===Early career=== Pastor embarked on a show business career at a very young age, obtaining a job singing at [[P.T. Barnum]]'s [[Barnum's American Museum|Scudder's American Museum]]. During the next few years he worked in [[minstrel show]]s, the circus business, and as a comic singer in variety revues. He established himself as a popular songwriter during a four-year run at [[Robert Butler (vaudevillian)|Robert Butler]]'s American Music Hall, a variety theater located at 444 Broadway in what is now called Soho but was then the heart of the lower Manhattan theater district. Pastor published "songsters", books of his lyrics which were sung to popular tunes. The music had no notation, as it was assumed that the audience had a collective knowledge of popular song. The subject matter of his music was intended to be bawdy and humorous.{{cite news |first= |last= |title=Tony Pastor and His 60 Years on the Stage |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=August 16, 1908 }} [[File:Tony-Pastor-02.JPG|left|thumb|225px|Tony Pastor and Bonnie Thornton (circa 1897)]] Though Pastor was popular with the nearly all-male variety theater audiences, he knew that his ticket sales would double if he attracted a female audience. Soon he began to produce [[variety shows]], presenting an evening of clean fun that was a distinct alternative to the bawdy shows of the time and more appropriate for middle-class families. In 1865 Pastor opened Tony Pastor's Opera House on the Bowery in partnership with [[minstrel show]] performer, Sam Sharpley, whom he later bought out. The same year he organized traveling minstrel troupes who toured the country annually between April and October. With shows that appealed to women and children as well as the traditional male audience, his theater and touring companies quickly became popular with the middle classes and were soon being imitated. In 1874, Pastor moved his company a few blocks to take over Michael Bennett Leavitt's former theater at 585 Broadway. The theater district was moving uptown to Union Square, however, and in 1881 Pastor took a lease on the former Germania Theatre on 14th Street in the same building that housed [[Tammany Hall]]. He alternated his theater's presentations between [[operetta]]s and family-oriented variety shows, creating what became known as [[vaudeville]]. His theater featured performers such as [[Ben Harney]] presenting a new style called "[[ragtime]]" as well as other up-and-coming talents such as [[Joe Weber (vaudevillian)|Weber]] and [[Lew Fields|Fields]], [[George M. Cohan]], [[Sophie Tucker]], [[Lillian Russell]], [[Buster Keaton]], [[Gus Edwards]], [[Eva Tanguay]], [[Blossom Seeley]], [[Benny Fields]], [[May Irwin]] and [[Eddie Leonard]]. Harry S. Sanderson was his business manager from 1878 until 1908. The business records from this period are available to researchers. In the musical [[Hello, Dolly! (musical)|Hello, Dolly!]], the song "Put On Your Sunday Clothes" includes the line, "We'll join the Astors at Tony Pastor's". It also references seeing "the shows at [[Delmonico's]]", which suggests that the character does not really know about upper class social life in New York. Tony Pastor died in [[Elmhurst, Queens|Elmhurst]], New York on August 26, 1908 and was interred in the [[Cemetery of the Evergreens]], in [[Brooklyn]]. He was 71, and though greatly mourned at his death as one of the last gentlemen of the early vaudeville halls, the medium had passed him by with the advent of the vaudeville circuit in the 1880s. Pastor had remained a local showman in an epoch that increasingly came to be dominated by regional and national chains. Fighting against the monopolies for the rights of individual local showmen was an undertaking that marked the last years of his life, earning him the nickname of "Little Man Tony".{{clear left}} ===Music=== According to the humor of the time, Pastor wrote several songs that negatively portrayed ethnic stereotypes, such as "The Contraband's Adventures", the story of a freed slave. After the slave is set free by [[Union Army|Union]] soldiers, he attends an anti-slavery meeting where the [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionists]] try to scrub off his dark pigment. The slave concludes by singing...
...De nigger will be nigger till de day of jubilee
For he never was intended for a white man.
Den just skedaddle home-leave de colored man alone;
For you're only making trouble for de nation;
You may fight and you may fuss
But you never will make tings right
Until you all agree for to let de nigger be
For you'll neber, neber, neber wash him white!
Though he separated some ethnic groups in his music, he also intended to unite the lower and middle classes. In songs like "The Upper and Lower Ten Thousand", he defended the common man of the Bowery:
If an [[Upper-Ten]] fellow a swindler should be
And with thousands of dollars of others make free
Should he get into court, why, without any doubt,
The matter's hushed up and they'll let him step out.
If a Lower-Ten Thousand chap happens to steal,
For to keep him from starving, the price of a meal,
Why the law will declare it's a different thing-
For they call him a thief, and he's sent to [[Sing-Sing]]!
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *{{findagrave|19966}} *[http://ibdb.com/venue.php?id=1576 Olympic Theatre] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pastor, Tony}} [[Category:Vaudeville performers]] [[Category:American theatre managers and producers]] [[Category:Blackface minstrel performers]] [[Category:Vaudeville producers]] [[Category:Impresarios]] [[Category:American people of Spanish descent]] [[Category:1837 births]] [[Category:1908 deaths]] [[Category:Burials at the Cemetery of the Evergreens]] [[Category:19th-century American singers]]

revision.comment: /* top */ More precisely define the scope of this topic. Does not have to be fictional, and does not apply to literature
revision.text:
{{distinguish|text=[[ghost character]] or a [[non-printing character]]}} {{specific|date=August 2016}} An '''unseen character''' in theatre, comics, film, or television, or '''silent character''' in radio, is a [[Character (arts)|character]] referred to but not directly known to the audience, but who advances the action of the plot in a significant way, and whose absence enhances their effect on the plot.<ref name="Mahfouz" /> The concept does not apply to the non-visual medium of [[literature]], where all characters are unseen by the reader.
The portrayal of an unseen character may vary depending on the form of media. In visual media such as film, stage or television, an unseen character may sometimes be partially depicted as body parts or an offscreen voice, but is still considered unseen as long as their face is never revealed.
== History == Unseen characters have been used since the beginning of theatre with the [[classical Greece|ancient Greek]] [[tragedy|tragedians]], such as [[Laius]] in [[Sophocles]]' ''[[Oedipus Rex]]'' and [[Jason]]'s bride in [[Euripides]]' [[Medea (play)|''Medea'']], and continued into Elizabethan theatre with examples such as Rosaline in [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare's]] ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]''.<ref name="Gray" /> However, it was the early twentieth-century European playwrights [[August Strindberg|Strindberg]], [[Henrik Ibsen|Ibsen]], and [[Anton Chekhov|Chekhov]] who fully developed the dramatic potential of the unseen character. [[Eugene O'Neill]] was influenced by his European contemporaries and established the absent character as an aspect of character, narrative, and stagecraft in [[Theater of the United States|American theatre]].<ref name="Mahfouz">{{cite journal|last1=Mahfouz|first1=Safi Mahmoud|title=The Presence of Absence: Catalytic and Omnipresent Offstage Characters in Modern American Drama.(Critical essay)|journal=The Midwest Quarterly|date=22 June 2012|volume=53|issue=4|pages=392(18)|url=https://www.questia.com/library/journal/1G1-297138820/the-presence-of-absence-catalytic-and-omnipresent|accessdate=8 August 2016|publisher=Pittsburg State University - Midwest Quarterly|language=English|issn=0026-3451}}</ref>
== Purpose and characteristics == Unseen characters are causal figures included in dramatic works to motivate the onstage characters to a certain course of action and advance the plot, but their presence is unnecessary. Indeed, their absence makes them appear more powerful because they are only known by inference.<ref name="Mahfouz" /> The use of an unseen character "take[s] advantage of one of the simplest but most powerful theatrical devices: the manner in which verbal references can make an offstage character extraordinarily real [...] to an audience," exploiting the audience's tendency to create visual images of imaginary characters in their mind.<ref name="Lawson">{{cite news|last1=Lawson|first1=Mark|title=Missing in action: meet the invisible stars of contemporary drama|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2015/apr/08/missing-in-action-contemporary-drama-unseen-stars|accessdate=4 February 2018|work=The Guardian|publisher=Trinity Mirror|date=8 April 2015|language=en}}</ref>
In a study of 18th-century French comedy, F. C. Green suggests that an "invisible character" can be defined as one who, though not seen, "influences the action of the play".<ref name="Green">{{cite book|author1=Frederick Charles Green|authorlink1=Frederick Charles Green|editor1-last=Jones|editor1-first=Percy Mansell|editor1-link=Percy Mansell Jones|editor2-last=Austin|editor2-first=L. J.|editor3-last=Reed|editor3-first=Garnet|editor4-last=Vinaver|editor4-first=Eugéne|title=Studies in Modern French Literature|chapter=Some Marginal Notes on Eighteenth-Century French Comedy|date=1961|publisher=Manchester University Press|location=Manchester|pages=133-137|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=VRa8AAAAIAAJ&lpg=PA133&pg=PA133#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=4 February 2018|language=en|quote=The invisible character may best be defined as a character who, although never shown to the audience, nevertheless influences the action of the play.}}</ref> This definition, according to Green, would rule out a character like Laurent (Lawrence), ''[[Tartuffe]]'s'' unseen valet, whose sole function is merely to give the playwright an opportunity to introduce Tartuffe.<ref name="Green" /><ref name="Tartuffe">{{cite wikisource|title=Tartuffe or the Hypocrite|last=Poquelin|first=Jean-Baptiste|author-link=Molière|others=Translated by [[Curtis Hidden Page]]|year=1664|chapter=Act II, Scene II}}</ref>
Unseen characters can develop organically even when their creators initially did not expect to keep them as unseen, especially in episodic works like television series. For instance, the producers of ''[[Cheers]]'' and ''[[Frasier]]'' initially did not want to make the character [[Niles Crane]]'s wife [[Minor characters on Frasier#Maris Crane|Maris]] an unseen character because they did not want to draw parallels to Vera, [[Norm Peterson]]'s wife on ''Cheers''. They originally intended that Maris would appear after several episodes, but were enjoying writing excuses for her absence so eventually it was decided she would remain unseen, and after the increasingly eccentric characteristics ascribed to her, no real actress could portray her.<ref name="Couch">{{cite AV media |people=Barbour, Jon (Producer); Khammar, Gary (Producer) |date=24 November 2003 |title=Behind the Couch: The Making of 'Frasier' |medium=DVD |volume=Season 1 |language=English |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1tKGHc-9Qyc |publisher=Paramount Home Entertainment}}</ref>
== Examples ==
===Comics=== * [[Al Capp]] introduced [[Lena the Hyena]] in June 1946 as an invisible character in the ''[[Li'l Abner]]'' newspaper strip. She was described as "the world's ugliest woman". Characters always reacted in fright when they saw her or an image of her but readers couldn't see her because she was hidden behind objects or out of frame. Eventually Capp organized a contest in which readers could send in their own graphic interpretations of what she might look like. The winner was cartoonist [[Basil Wolverton]], whose design was first shown in the 21 October 1946 strip.<ref>https://www.lambiek.net/artists/w/wolverton.htm</ref> * In [[Merho]]'s comics series ''[[De Kiekeboes]]'' Mevrouw Stokvis, a friend of Moemoe Kiekeboe, is always mentioned or referred to, but has never actually been seen in the series.<ref>https://www.lambiek.net/artists/m/merho.htm</ref>
=== Theatre === Unseen characters occur elsewhere in drama, including the plays of [[Eugene O'Neill]], [[Tennessee Williams]], and [[Edward Albee]].<ref name="Byrd">{{cite journal|last1=Byrd|first1=Robert E. Jr.|title=Unseen characters in selected plays of Eugene O'Neill, Tennessee Williams, and Edward Albee|journal=Dissertation Abstracts International|date=1998|volume=58|issue=12A|page=4497|url=http://catalog.xmu.edu.cn/opac/item.php?marc_no=0003391725|publisher=New York University|location=New York}}</ref><ref name="Ade">{{cite news|last1=Ade|first1=George|title=Introducing "Nettie"; Who Is the Leading But Unseen Character in a New Princess Playlet|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E05E0D6133EE733A05755C0A9649D946596D6CF|work=The New York Times|date=6 December 1914}}</ref> Author Marie A. Wellington notes that in the 18th-century, [[Voltaire]] included unseen characters in a few of his plays, including ''Le Duc d’Alençon'' and ''L’Orphelin de la Chine''.<ref name="Wellington">{{cite book|last1=Wellington|first1=Marie|title=The Art of Voltaire's Theater: An Exploration of Possibility|date=1987|publisher=Lang|location=New York|isbn=9780820404837|page=176|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/The_Art_of_Voltaire_s_Theater.html?id=wRUbAQAAIAAJ}}</ref>
* [[Rosaline]] in [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' is never seen, but is only described.<ref name="Gray">{{cite journal|last1=Gray|first1=Henry David|title=Romeo, Rosaline, and Juliet|journal=Modern Language Notes|date=November 1914|volume=29|issue=7|pages=209-212|doi=10.2307/2916173|url=https://archive.org/details/jstor-2916173|accessdate=4 February 2018}}</ref><ref name="Miller">{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Michael|title='Romeo and Juliet' meets Jeff Buckley in 'The Last Goodbye'|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-romeo-julet-last-goodbye-globe-20130929-story.html|accessdate=16 May 2014|work=Los Angeles Times|date=27 September 2013}}</ref> * In [[Alain-René Lesage]]'s 1707 play ''[[Crispin rival de son maître|Crispin]]'' an unseen character called Damis with his forced secret marriage is essential to the plot.<ref name="Green" /> * In [[Clare Boothe Luce]]'s play ''[[The Women (play)|The Women]]'' (1936), and the [[The Women (1939 film)|1939 film based on the play]], male characters (husbands, lovers, etc.) are referred to but do not appear, even in photographs.<ref name="IBDB">{{cite web|title=The Women|url=http://www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=9750|website=Internet Broadway Database|accessdate=21 September 2013}}</ref><ref name="Goldstein">{{cite book|last1=Goldstein|first1=Malcolm|editor1-last=Cody|editor1-first=Gabrielle H.|editor2-last=Sprinchorn|editor2-first=Evert|title=The Columbia Encyclopedia of Modern Drama|volume=2|date=2007|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York, NY|isbn=9780231144247|page=1489|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=aQqOKWmjdQUC&lpg=PA1489|language=en|chapter=The Women}}</ref> * Godot in [[Samuel Beckett]]'s ''[[Waiting for Godot]]'' is never seen. The play's two main characters spend the entire play waiting for Godot to arrive.<ref name="Bennett">{{cite book|last1=Bennett|first1=Michael Y.|title=Reassessing the Theatre of the Absurd: Camus, Beckett, Ionesco, Genet, and Pinter|date=2011|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=9780230118829|page=27|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=wbTGAAAAQBAJ|doi=10.1057/9780230118829|language=en|chapter=The Parable of Estragon's Struggle with the Boot in Samuel Beckett's ''Waiting for Godot''|accessdate=4 February 2018}}</ref> * In [[Anton Chekhov]]'s play ''[[Three Sisters (play)|Three Sisters]]'', Protopopov, who is cuckolding his employee Andrei and having a torrid and far from secret affair with Natasha, is unseen but plays a central role. Some sources suggest Protopopov, not Andrei, is the real father of Sofia, Natasha's daughter.<ref name="Styan">{{cite book|last1=Styan|first1=John L.|title=The Elements of Drama|date=1960|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=9780521092012|page=209|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/The_Elements_of_Drama.html?id=bOnd4QuAJHgC|language=en|chapter=The Meaning of the Play as a Whole}}</ref><ref name="threesisters">{{cite wikisource |title=The Three Sisters |wslink=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Plays_by_Anton_Tchekoff/The_Three_Sisters |last=Chekhov |first=Anton |authorlink=Anton Chekhov |other=Translated by [[Julius West]] |year=1916 |chapter=Act IV |chapter-url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Plays_by_Anton_Tchekoff/The_Three_Sisters/Act_IV |quote=NATASHA: Mihail Ivanitch Protopopov will sit with little Sophie, and Andrey Sergeyevitch can take little Bobby out. […] [Stage direction] ANDREY wheels out the perambulator in which BOBBY is sitting.}}</ref>
=== UK television and radio === * ''[[Minder (TV series)|Minder]]'': [[Arthur Daley]]'s wife, referred to only as "'Er Indoors", is never seen or heard, but often quoted.<ref name="erindoors">{{cite news|title='Er indoors enters the lexicon|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/er-indoors-enters-the-lexicon-1580557.html|accessdate=15 May 2014|work=The Independent|date=30 August 1992}}</ref> *In ''[[Keeping Up Appearances]]'', Hyacinth Bucket has a phone conversation in each episode with her son Sheridan, who has moved out and is attending college.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/comment/top-30-characters-you-never-see-out-of-sight-but-in-your-mind-10047794.html "Top 30 Characters You Never See: out of sight, but in your mind"]. ''[[The Independent]]'', February 16, 2015.</ref> A photograph of a young boy meant to depict Sheridan in childhood appears in the opening credits, but the character is never seen as an adult. The running gag in these conversations is that Hyacinth remains persistently oblivious to all the evidence that her son is [[gay]]. *In the long-running British radio soap opera ''[[The Archers]]'', a number of permanent inhabitants of the village in which the story is set are frequently referred to but are never heard in their own voices. Fans of the programme often refer to these characters as "[[List of The Archers characters#Silent characters|the silents]]".<ref name="silents">{{cite news|last1=Cunningham|first1=Jennifer|title=In praise of … silent Archers characters|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/comment/guest-commentary/in-praise-of-silent-archers-characters-1.1092492|accessdate=9 November 2014|work=The Herald|publisher=Herald & Times Group|date=25 March 2011|archiveurl=https://www.pressreader.com/uk/the-herald/20110325/282892317178777|archive-date=25 March 2011|location=Glasgow}}</ref> *Throughout the entire 18-year run of ''[[Heartbeat (UK TV series)|Heartbeat]]'', PC Alf Ventress refers to his wife Mrs. Ventress, but she is neither seen nor is her first name ever revealed.<ref>https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/tvs-best-invisible-characters-outed-20150113-12i6kk.html</ref>
=== US television === * On the mystery drama ''[[Columbo]]'', Lieutenant Columbo often describes his wife in detail but she is never seen, heard, or otherwise portrayed in the series.<ref name="museum">{{cite web|title=Profile of ''Columbo''|url=http://www.museum.tv/eotv/columbo.htm|website=Encyclopedia of Television|publisher=The Museum of Broadcast Communications|accessdate=16 May 2014}}</ref><ref name="NME25best">{{cite web|author1=NME Picture Desk|title=The 25 Best TV Characters You Never See On Screen - NME|url=http://www.nme.com/photos/the-25-best-tv-characters-you-never-see-on-screen-1408066|website=NME|accessdate=4 February 2018|date=14 June 2016}}</ref> A short-lived, unsuccessful spin-off series ''[[Mrs. Columbo (TV series)|Mrs. Columbo]]'' was created in 1979 after ''Columbo'' had ended its run, but Lieutenant Columbo never appeared. ''[[Mrs. Columbo (TV series)|Mrs. Columbo]]'', as played by [[Kate Mulgrew]], was named Kate (although Lieutenant Columbo's wife in ''Columbo'' was never given a name). The series gradually severed all ties with the original detective series. Both the series and the character herself were renamed in an attempt to change direction, but this did not help the poor ratings and the series was ultimately canceled in March 1980 after only thirteen episodes had aired.<ref name="totally">{{cite web|url=http://www.totallykate.com/mrscolum/katemyst.htm|title=Kate Loves a Mystery|accessdate=May 14, 2016}}</ref><ref name="freeuk">{{cite web|url=http://www.columbo-site.freeuk.com/mrsc.htm|title=Mrs. Columbo Revealed!|accessdate=July 29, 2016}}</ref> * On ''[[The Mary Tyler Moore Show]]'', Phyllis Lindstrom's husband, Dr. Lars Lindstrom, is oft-referenced but never seen.<ref name="mentalfloss11">{{cite news|last1=Lascala|first1=Marisa|title=11 Famous TV Characters We Never Actually Saw|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/54533/11-famous-television-characters-we-never-actually-saw|accessdate=15 May 2014|work=Mental Floss|date=25 November 2015|language=en}}</ref> * On ''[[Rhoda]]'', Carlton, the doorman in [[Rhoda Morgenstern]]'s apartment building, is often heard on the intercom (voiced by [[Lorenzo Music]]) but almost never seen – only his arm would occasionally appear from doors and he was once shown dancing and conversing while wearing a gorilla mask. After ''Rhoda'' ended its run, Carlton was featured as an animated character in the 1980 spin-off special ''[[Carlton Your Doorman]]''. Once again voiced by Music, Carlton is shown as a young man with shoulder-length blond hair and mustache.<ref name="toptenz10">{{cite news|last1=Macauley|first1=Marnie|title=10 Legendary TV Characters We’ve Never Seen|url=https://www.toptenz.net/10-legendary-tv-characters-weve-never-seen.php|accessdate=4 October 2014|work=Top TENZ|date=29 October 2018|language=en}}</ref> * On ''[[Seinfeld]]'', Bob Sacamano, Lomez, and "Cousin Jeffrey" are often mentioned but never seen.<ref name="NME25best" /> The first two are friends of [[Cosmo Kramer]], and the last is the cousin of [[Jerry Seinfeld (character)|Jerry Seinfeld]]. Jeffrey works for the New York City Parks Department, as Jerry is told ''[[ad nauseam]]'' by his [[Uncle Leo]].<ref name="ugo">{{cite news|last1=Fitzpatrick|first1=Kevin|title=TV's Best Characters (That You're Not Allowed To See)|url=http://www.ugo.com/tv/unseen-tv-characters?page=2|accessdate=15 May 2014|work=UGO|publisher=IGN Entertainment|date=8 December 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517120128/http://www.ugo.com/tv/unseen-tv-characters?page=2|archivedate=17 May 2014|page=2}}</ref> George Costanza also spent some time working for [[George Steinbrenner]], the owner of the [[New York Yankees]]; however, Steinbrenner (as portrayed by series co-creator [[Larry David]]) was only ever shown as the back of his head in his office chair, and his face was never seen on camera.<ref name=collegehumor>[http://www.collegehumor.com/post/5096683/12-television-characters-we-never-see-even-though-they-were-on-tv "12 Television Characters We Never See (Even Though They Were On TV)"]. ''[[CollegeHumor]]'', July 1, 2009.</ref> * On ''[[The Andy Griffith Show]]'', Juanita Beasley, for whom [[Barney Fife]] occasionally expresses affection, is unseen but often referenced and telephoned by the love-struck Fife.<ref name="mentalfloss11" /> * In ''[[Charlie's Angels]]'', the titular Charlie Townsend, the owner of the detective agency that employed the series leads, was never seen, and was portrayed solely as a voice (provided by actor [[John Forsythe]]) heard on a speakerphone.<ref name=nme>[https://www.nme.com/photos/the-25-best-tv-characters-you-never-see-on-screen-1408066 "The 25 Best TV Characters You Never See On Screen"]. ''[[NME]]'', June 14, 2016.</ref> *[[Norm Peterson|Vera Peterson]] from ''[[Cheers]]'' and [[Minor characters on Frasier#Maris Crane|Maris Crane]] from its spin-off ''[[Frasier]]'' are two of the most widely recognized unseen characters of American television,<ref name="Deseret">{{cite news|last1=Pierce|first1=Scott D.|title=Maris is missing in another great episode of 'Frasier'|url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/453375/MARIS-IS-MISSING-IN-ANOTHER-GREAT-EPISODE-OF-FRASIER.html|work=Deseret News|date=28 November 1995|language=en|quote=Maris Crane is missing! Actually, Maris Crane has always been missing. The thin and Caucasian wife of Dr. Niles Crane (David Hyde Pierce) has never actually been seen on "Frasier" - although she's been a frequent presence on the show. And the unseen Maris plays a major part in a don't-miss episode of this excellent, Emmy-winning comedy.}}</ref><ref name="mentalfloss11" /><ref name="Hines">{{cite news|last1=Hines|first1=Ree|title=Favorite TV characters that no one ever played|url=http://www.today.com/id/28508535/ns/today-entertainment/t/favorite-tv-characters-no-one-ever-played/|accessdate=4 February 2018|work=NBC TODAY|publisher=NBCUniversal|date=5 January 2009|language=en}}</ref><ref name="Endrst">{{cite news|last1=Endrst|first1=James|title=These TV Series Stars Are Out of Sight|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-12-12/entertainment/ca-13171_1_charlie-townsend|accessdate=4 February 2018|work=Los Angeles Times|date=12 December 1995|quote=Like so many of TV's unseen stars, Maris is one of our most beloved characters, someone we're free to color in the way we choose, a figure who adds mystery, imagination, an X-factor to the show.}}</ref><ref name="Matheson">{{cite news|last1=Matheson|first1=Whitney|title=Some things onscreen are best left unseen|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/columnist/popcandy/2005-03-22-pop-candy_x.htm|accessdate=4 February 2018|work=USA Today|date=22 March 2005}}</ref><ref name="Dawidziak">{{cite news|last1=Dawidziak|first1=Mark|title='Big Bang Theory's' Mrs. Wolowitz is the latest in a long line of enigmatic invisible TV characters|url=http://www.cleveland.com/tv-blog/index.ssf/2012/12/big_bang_theorys_mrs_wolowitz_is_the_latest_in_a_long_line_of_enigmatic_invisible_tv_characters.html|accessdate=4 February 2018|work=cleveland.com|publisher=Advance Ohio|date=7 December 2012}}</ref><ref name="NME25best" /> though Vera's body (with her face obscured by a pie)<ref name=collegehumor/> is seen in one episode, and her voice is heard in other episodes. Her voice was provided by Bernadette Birkett, the real-life wife of [[George Wendt]] who portrayed Norm Peterson, leading Wendt to comment that he never personally wondered what Vera looked like.<ref name=nme/> Maris is also seen as a silhouette. *Stan Walker, the wealthy husband of Karen Walker on ''[[Will & Grace]]'', has been depicted on screen only as hands and feet.<ref name=nme/> Karen and Stan have divorced twice over the show's run, once after Stan faked his own death, leading the website ''[[CollegeHumor]]'' to label him as the one unseen character who "arguably drives the plot more than any other unseen character on a TV show."<ref name=collegehumor/>
